title: Control the Center
description: Learn why controlling the center is key to winning

steps.text: The center squares (e4, d4, e5, d5) are the most important squares on the board. Pieces placed here control more squares and can reach both sides of the board quickly.
Play 1.e4 ‚Äî this pawn controls d5 and f5, and opens lines for the queen and bishop.

exercise.hint: Move the king's pawn two squares forward

steps.text: After 1.e4 e5, White plays 2.d4 to claim even more central space. Two pawns abreast in the center is a powerful formation.

exercise.hint: Push the queen's pawn two squares forward

steps.text: Knights are also excellent central pieces. A knight on e4 or d5 controls up to 8 squares, compared to only 2-4 on the rim.
Compare: a knight on a1 controls only 2 squares, while a knight on d4 controls 8. Always aim for the center!

title: Piece Development
description: Get your pieces into the game quickly and efficiently

steps.text: Development means moving your pieces from their starting squares to active squares where they control the board. Develop knights and bishops before the queen.
Develop the kingside knight to f3 ‚Äî it controls the center and prepares castling.

exercise.hint: Develop the knight toward the center

steps.text: Now develop the bishop. Bc4 eyes the vulnerable f7 square and prepares castling.

exercise.hint: Place the bishop on an active diagonal

steps.text: Avoid moving the same piece twice in the opening, or bringing out the queen too early. She can be chased around by minor pieces, wasting time.
The Italian Game after 3...Bc5 shows good development by both sides. All minor pieces aim at the center.

title: King Safety & Castling
description: Protect your king by castling early

steps.text: The king is safest behind a wall of pawns. Castling tucks the king away and connects the rooks. You should castle within the first 10 moves.
Castle kingside now! Move the king to g1 ‚Äî this is the most common and safest castle.
After castling, the king is safe on g1 with pawns on f2, g2, h2 forming a protective shelter. The rook is also activated on f1.
Danger! If you don't castle, the king can get stuck in the center. Here White's king is exposed to a devastating attack.
Don't weaken your castled king's pawn shield unnecessarily. Moves like h3, g4 can create targets for your opponent's attack.

title: Pawn Structure
description: Understand how pawns shape the game

steps.text: Pawns are the soul of chess. They can't move backward, so every pawn move permanently changes the position. Pawn structure determines which pieces are strong or weak.
Doubled pawns (two pawns on the same file) are usually a weakness. They can't protect each other and are hard to advance.
An isolated pawn has no friendly pawns on adjacent files to protect it. It becomes a target. Here the d4 pawn is isolated.
A passed pawn has no enemy pawns blocking or guarding its path. Passed pawns must be pushed! They can become queens.
Push the passed pawn forward! A passed pawn on d5 is a powerful asset.

title: Tactical Patterns: Forks
description: Attack two pieces at once with forks

steps.text: A fork is when one piece attacks two or more enemy pieces at the same time. Knights are the best forking pieces because they jump over other pieces.
Knight fork! Move the knight to c7 to fork the king and rook simultaneously.

exercise.hint: This is a setup move first

steps.text: Here's a classic knight fork position. Play Nf7+ to fork the king and queen!
Find the fork! Move the knight to d6 to attack both the king and the bishop at once.

exercise.hint: The knight can attack the king and rook

steps.text: Pawns can fork too! Here e5 attacks both the knight on d6 and the bishop on f6.

title: Tactical Patterns: Pins & Skewers
description: Use line pieces to restrict and win material

steps.text: A pin occurs when a piece cannot move because doing so would expose a more valuable piece behind it. Only bishops, rooks, and queens can pin.
The bishop on g5 pins the knight on f6 to the queen on d8. The knight cannot move without losing the queen!
Pin the knight! Move the bishop to b5 to pin the knight on c6 to the king on e8.

exercise.hint: Place the bishop to pin the knight against the king

steps.text: A skewer is the reverse of a pin ‚Äî you attack a valuable piece that must move, then capture the piece behind it. Here Bb5+ skewers the king and rook.
Find the skewer! Move the rook to e1 to skewer the queen and king on the e-file.

exercise.hint: Use the rook to attack along the e-file

title: Basic Endgames
description: Learn essential king and pawn endings

steps.text: In the endgame, the king becomes a powerful piece. Bring your king to the center! The king must be active to support pawn promotion.
The key concept is opposition: kings face each other with one square between them. The side NOT to move has the opposition (an advantage).
King and queen vs king: use the queen to restrict the opposing king to the edge, then bring your king close for checkmate.
Push the pawn! In king and pawn endings, advancing a passed pawn with king support is the path to victory.

exercise.hint: Advance the pawn while your king supports it

steps.text: The square rule: if the defending king can reach the 'square' of the pawn (imaginary square from pawn to promotion rank), it draws. Otherwise the pawn promotes.
Advance the pawn! The black king is too far away to catch it.

exercise.hint: Push the h-pawn ‚Äî the black king can't catch it

title: Thinking Process (CCT)
description: Checks, Captures, Threats ‚Äî a systematic approach

steps.text: Before every move, use the CCT method: look at all Checks first, then Captures, then Threats. This systematic approach helps you find the best move.
Step 1 ‚Äî Checks: Always look for checks first. A check forces your opponent to respond, giving you the initiative. Find the check here!
Step 2 ‚Äî Captures: After checks, look for captures. Can you win material? Here White can capture the undefended knight.
Step 3 ‚Äî Threats: If no checks or captures, look for threats. A threat forces your opponent to deal with your plan. Here Ng5 threatens Nxf7.
Practice CCT in every game. Before moving, ask: Are there any checks? Any captures that win material? Any threats I can create? This simple habit will dramatically improve your play.
